t: Job 10
I*pn am disgusted with my life. I*ln will give vent to my complaint and*ln speak in the bitterness of my soul.
I*ln will say to God, “Do*ln not declare me guilty! Let*ln me know why you prosecute me.
Is*ln it good for you to oppress, to*ln reject the work of your hands, and*ln favor the plans of the wicked?
Do*ln you have eyes of flesh, or*ln do you see as a human sees?
Are*ln your days like those of a human, or*ln your years like those of a man,
that*ln you look for my iniquity and*ln search for my sin,
even*ln though you know that I am not wicked and*ln that there is no one who can rescue from your power?
“Your*pn hands shaped me and formed me. Will*ln you now turn and destroy me?
Please*ln remember that you formed me like clay. Will*ln you now return me to dust?
Did*ln you not pour me out like milk and*ln curdle me like cheese?
You*ln clothed me with skin and flesh, and*ln wove me together with bones and tendons.
You*ln gave me life and faithful love, and*ln your care has guarded my life.
“Yet*pn you concealed these thoughts in your heart; I*ln know that this was your hidden plan:
if*ln I sin, you would notice, and*ln would not acquit me of my iniquity.
If*ln I am wicked, woe to me! And*ln even if I am righteous, I cannot lift up my head. I*ln am filled with shame and*ln have drunk deeply of my affliction.
If*ln I am proud, you hunt me like a lion and*ln again display your miraculous power against me.
You*ln produce new witnesses against me and*ln multiply your anger toward me. Hardships*ln assault me, wave after wave.
“Why*pn did you bring me out of the womb? I*ln should have died and never been seen.
I*ln wish I had never existed but*ln had been carried from the womb to the grave.
Are*ln my days not few? Stop it! Leave*ln me alone, so that I can smile a little
before*ln I go to a land of darkness and gloom, never*ln to return.
It*ln is a land of blackness like the deepest darkness, gloomy*ln and chaotic, where*ln even the light is like the darkness.”
